Description: Terracotta scarab-mould in Nile clay; front face of mould is flat, back is rounded, roughly conical; scarab impression is choked with pale greenish turquoise core material; no detail of scarab body now visible; in pale red shading to grey Nile silt fabric, with mica inclusions.
Dimensions: Diameter: 1.62 centimetres (mould from front face to back)
Depth: 0.33 centimetres (impression to top of choked material)
Curator's comments: The mould content was analysed by proton induced X-ray emission spectrometry (PIXE) under a 3 MeV energy proton beam for characterisation of the elemental chemical composition (major, minor and trace elements), in March 2014, by the Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musées de France (C2RMF). Glazed composition scarabs and scaraboids produced at Naukratis were usually cast and not carved or incised; this technique, highly characteristic of Naukratite productions, allowed a mass-production of these small objects which were mainly intended for export in the whole Mediterranean area and even as far as Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 177-180, fig. 35). Numerous terracotta moulds for scarabs, scaraboids and amulets were discovered at the site (on the various productions from the Scarab Factory see Webb, forthcoming). Petrie listed a number of variants for scarab and scaraboid-moulds (Petrie 1886, 36-37, pl. XXXVIII, 1-11). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (E89)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OH.030) (phase 2)
